taxonomicNotes: Specimens formerly considered Bolitoglossa robinisoni from Valle El Silencio are now thought to belong to this species (E. Arias pers. comm. September 2019).
This species was confused with Bolitoglossa pesrubra prior to its naming (Wake et al. 2007). It has been determined by mtDNA phylogeny to be part of the B. subpalmata clade (Boza-Oveido et al. 2012).
Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.

Records of eastern Atlantic Myliobatis aquila from southern Brazil probably refer to this species, if both species are indeed distinct (if not, the name M. aquila has priority). There are two sister species in the southern part of its range under the present name M. goodei, with a description of the second species pending (Ruocco et al. 2012).
The Bignose Shark is morphologically distinct but genetically similar to the Sandbar Shark (Carcharhinus plumbeus) (Naylor et al. 2012, Duffy and Struthers 2017).
The specimens tentatively assigned to this species might represent four to five different species (Bolaños and Wake 2009, Hertz 2015).
The northern subspecies, Anolis lemurinus bourgeaei, has sometimes been treated as a full species. Anolis rhombifer was synonymized within A. lemurinus by Fitch and Seigel (1984).

The only record from Mexico was of one specimen reportedly collected from Cozumel over 100 years ago and described as ANOLIS cozumelae. Closer inspection of the specimen found this to be a specimen of A. cristatellus, but it has not been reported again on the island and there is now significant doubt regards the validity of this record.

Anolis quaggulus was removed from synonymy with A. humilis by Köhler (2003), but the diagnostic characters this author uses to distinguish the two taxa are considered insufficient by Poe et al. (2016). Anolis humilis marsupialis was elevated to specific status by Savage and Bolaños (2009), an action upheld by Köhler et al. (2015).
Both Hulebak and Poe (2006) and Ponce and Köhler (2008) synonymized Anolis pandoensis within Anolis kemptoni.

G. Köhler (pers. comm. 2012) suggests that records from the Pacific versant presently included within this species may represent a separate species, for which the name Anolis pulchripes is available, but taxonomic research is needed to confirm this. Poe (2016) notes that the characters used to distinguish this species from Anolis zeus, presently recognized as a distinct species, are not reliable.
Several Panamanian populations previously referred to as Anolis microtus are now referred to as Anolis ginaelisae Lotzkat, Hertz, Bienentreu & Köhler, 2013.

There remains some confusion as to whether Anolis lionotus is a separate species from the very similar A. oxylophus, a situation complicated by the apparent loss of the Panamanian A. lionotus holotype (Wilson et al. 2010). Citing unpublished work, Köhler (2001) justified earlier works (Köhler 1999, 2000) that treated A. oxylophus as a synonym without comment. As no published work has yet formally synonymized these taxa, however, this account follows Savage (2002) and Wilson et al. (2010) in considering A. lionotus a separate species from A. oxylophus, with A. oxylophus ranging from Honduras to western Panama.
Was formerly treated as part of Anolis sericeus.
Lotzkat et al. (2011) revised the taxonomy of Anolis pachypus, confining it to Panama and extreme southern Costa Rica. Records further north represent Anolis tropidolepis and A. magnaphallus.

This species is sometimes confused with Rhinoptera bonasus, which can only be distinguished by counting the series of toothplates. Rhinoptera bonasus usually have seven series of plates in both jaws, while R. brasiliensis teeth are typically arranged in series of nine (Last et al. 2016).

Molecular data and morphological, ecological, and demographic analyses suggest that the Panamanian golden frogs and their kin (the Atelopus varius-zeteki clade) are comprised of five distinct forms (Zippel et al. 2006). The species has a variable appearance and color and pattern are poor diagnostic characteristics for identification of this species (Richards and Knowles 2007). Some subpopulations have a very yellow color, resembling Atelopus zeteki, which is why both Atelopus varius and Atelopus zeteki are sometimes referred to as golden frogs in Panama (Estrada et al. 2014). Genetic analysis of mitochondrial DNA reveals support for recognizing A. varius and A. zeteki as separate clades, but sorting of haplotypes was imperfect and Costa Rican samples sorted into a third outlying group (Richards and Knowles 2007). Genetic examination of the phylogeny of this group would be helpful, but the extreme declines of this group will make sourcing of fresh, genomic quality tissues challenging.
Some records from Antioquia and Chocó Departments in Colombia have been reassigned to Cochranella mache (Jaramillo-Martinez et al. 2015).

At present, this species is considered to be a complex of several taxa and is currently undergoing taxonomic revision (T. Grant pers. comm.). The identity of frogs assigned to S. nubicola in the mountains along the Colombia-Panama border is equivocal (Grant and Myers 2013).

This is a restricted concept of Cruziohyla calcarifer following the split of the broader concept into this and Cruziohyla sylviae (Gray 2018). With the recognition of Cruziohyla sylviae, the literature of Cruziohyla calcarifer becomes suspect as to whether addressing Cruziohyla sylviae, Cruziohyla calcarifer, or both (Frost 2019).
More than one species may currently be included within Agalychnis spurrelli (Federico Bolaños pers. comm.). Agalychnis litodryas has been synonymized with this species (Frost 2014).

"Although Triprion spinosus has been considered a species with a wide distribution, from southeastern Mexico to western Panama (Duellman, 1970), the 16S fragment of our specimen from Honduras differs from those of Oaxaca in 2.9%. Better understanding of the sequence variation among these samples and those from the easternmost part of the distribution of T. spinosus is required, but a taxonomic revision of the different populations assigned to this species seems to be necessary" (Faivovich et al. 2018).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). Genetic distances suggest that more than one species might be combined under this name (Faivovich et al. 2018). Specimens from the Serranía de Tabasará may represent a distinct species (Hertz 2015).

This species was previously within the genus Phyllomedusa but was moved to the genus Hylomantis by Faivovich et al. (2005). Subsequently, it was moved from Hylomantis to Agalychnis by Favivovich et al. (2010).

This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). The current taxonomic concept probably contains several cryptic species (Crawford et al. 2013; R. Ibanez pers. comm June 2018).

This species is thought to be a complex containing multiple conspecific lineages (Batista et al. 2014; A. Crawford pers. comm. 2018). We depart from the taxonomic split of Pristimantis educatoris from this species proposed by Ryan et al. (2010) and treat the Colombian and Panamanian specimens under this name, following Batista et al. (2014), until taxonomic work is properly carried out to delimit the undescribed species.

This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). This is a restricted concept of Craugastor podiciferus following the split of the broader concept into this Craugastor sagui, C. zungai and C. blairi (Arias et al. 2019).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
Localities in the Caribbean drainage of northern Costa Rica, as mentioned by Brame and Wake (1963) refer to misidentified specimens of Bolitoglossa alvaradoi (Hertz 2015).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Dermophis mexicanus by Savage and Wake (2001). Its taxonomic status is unclear, and the conspecificity of the disjunct populations is unknown.
Savage and Wake (2001) removed this species from synonymy with Dermophis parviceps. Its taxonomic status is unclear.

This species is sometimes confused with Rhinoptera brasiliensis, which can only be distinguished from R. bonasus by counting the series of toothplates. Rhinoptera bonasus usually have seven series of plates in both jaws, while R. brasiliensis teeth are typically arranged in series of nine (Last et al. 2016).
Castro (2011) resurrected Carcharhinus cerdale, considering it distinct from C. porosus. Carcharhinus cerdale is restricted to the Eastern Pacific and C. porosus to the Western Atlantic.
Previously confused with the similar but smaller Etmopterus pusillus until described as a distinct species by Shirai and Tachikawa (1993).
This species is sometimes confused with Squalus clarkae and may be confused with recently described or undescribed species in the South Atlantic (C.F. Cotton unpubl. data 2020).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). Faivovich et al. (2018) found considerable genetic differences between Costa Rican specimens from the type locality at Volcán Barva, the high Talamanca in western Panama, and the specimen from Cerro Saguí. It might be that this is a complex of several species (A. Hertz pers. comm. June 2018).

Until recently, Central American capuchins were considered to be subspecies of Cebus capucinus; however, recent genetic analyses (Boubli et al. 2012) suggest a phylogenetic division between C. capuchinus from South America and Eastern Panama and the Central American populations with no evidence of division within the latter group.
Blainville’s Beaked Whales (Mesoplodon densirostris) is one of 15 species of Mesoplodon with a worldwide range in tropical and warm-temperate waters. No subspecies are currently recognized.

Mesoplodon peruvianus was first described in 1991 (Reyes et al. 1991) based on specimens from Peru. Prior to that, beginning in the late 1970s, there had been numerous sightings of a distinctively patterned, but unidentified, mesoplodont during regular cetacean surveys in the eastern tropical Pacific. These were originally referred to in the survey sighting records and earlier publications as “Mesoplodon sp. A” (Pitman et al. 1987), but after the description of M. peruvianus, it was suggested that M. sp. A was, in fact, M. peruvianus (Pitman and Lynn 2001). This contention was later confirmed by genetic analysis of a fresh-stranded Mesoplodon in western Mexico with the same diagnostic color pattern (Urbán et al. 2013).

Cuvier’s Beaked Whale (Ziphius cavirostris) is the only species in the monotypic genus Ziphius (Rice 1998, Dalebout et al. 2005). During the 19th century numerous specimens of Cuvier’s Beaked Whales were described as new species but none of them have been accepted as valid and a single species is recognized to occur throughout its range.

authority: Boza-Oviedo, Rovito, Chaves, García-Rodríguez, Artavia, Bolaños & Wake, 2012
Boza-Oviedo, Rovito, Chaves, García-Rodríguez, Artavia, Bolaños & Wake, 2012
Boza-Oviedo, Rovito, Chaves, García-Rodríguez, Artavia, Bolaños & Wake, 2012
taxonomicNotes: Taxonomic work is underway to clarify the validity of this species. Genetic analysis suggests that this taxon may be conspecific with Nototriton picadoi (B. Kubicki and E. Arias pers. comm. September 2019).
This is a restricted concept of Oedipina pseudouniformis following the split of the broader concept into this and Oedipina koehleri (Sunyer et al. 2011).

authority: Boza-Oviedo, Rovito, Chaves, García-Rodríguez, Artavia, Bolaños & Wake, 2012

taxonomicNotes: The identity of a record from Limón, Costa Rica (see Savage 2002) is uncertain (Costa Rica Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).

Hyalinobatrachium crybetes has been made a synonym of this species, although the Honduran subpopulation previously assigned to H. crybetes needs to be confirmed using fresh material, as it either belongs to H. colymbiphyllum or H. fleischmanni (Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid 2007).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). Genetic distances and morphological characteristics suggest that more than one species might be currently combined under this name (Faivovich et al. 2018).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was later moved to the genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). Faivovich et al. (2018) found a high genetic diversity among different specimens. It is doubtful that the subpopulations between Monteverde in Costa Rica and western Panama are the same species (A. Hertz pers. comm. June 2018).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
There may be more than one distinct species within this taxon, but this needs to be verified through taxonomic research (Hertz 2015, Panama Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019).
It is possible that this species is a complex, with at least three distinct species in Panama (Hertz 2015).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Dermophis mexicanus by Savage and Wake (2001).
This taxon may be a synonym of Hyalinobatrachium talamancae, and further studies are needed to resolve this (B. Kubicki pers. comm.).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was subsequently moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). Additional specimens are needed to better determine the validity of this species (F. Bolaños pers. comm. September 2019).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). The systematic status of Craugastor cuaquero remains somewhat unclear, and it is possible that this may not represent a valid species (F. Bolaños pers. comm.).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). It was separated from Eleutherodactylus bransfordii by Savage (2002).

This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). Additional taxonomic work is needed to decisively confirm the validity of this species (F. Bolaños pers. comm.).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). Further taxonomic studies are needed to confirm the validity of this species (F. Bolaños pers. comm.)
There are considerable taxonomic problems with this species. The systematic status of the subpopulation from Tapant<span class="msoIns">í needs to be resolved (F. Bolaños pers. comm. 2007, 2019).

Subpopulations in south-east Costa Rica and north-west Panama have been separated as Bolitoglossa sombra and B. magnifica (Hanken et al. 2005). However, this species and B. sombra appear to be genetically similar and may actually represent the same species (E. Arias pers. comm. September 2019).

This form was formerly considered to be part of Bolitoglossa subpalmata, but has since been removed from synonymy (Savage 2002). Several species might still be involved in what is now considered B. pesrubra.
As assessed here, this taxon is restricted to northern Costa Rica (Savage 2000). It is possible that the southwest subpopulation may be described as a new species (F. Bolaños pers. comm.).
The eastern subpopulations (e.g., San Ramon) are taxonomically uncertain (B. Kubicki and E. Arias pers. comm. September 2019).
Genetic analysis suggests that Nototriton matama and N. major may be conspecific with this species (B. Kubicki and E. Arias pers. comm. September 2019).
This species was resurrected from synonymy of Dermophis mexicanus by Savage and Wake (2001). Its taxonomic status is unclear.
This species was described from specimens that were earlier provisionally assigned to Bolitoglossa nigrescens (Hanken et al. 2005).

This species was described from specimens that were earlier provisionally assigned to Bolitoglossa nigrescens (Hanken et al. 2005). This taxon is similar to B. nigresens and B. obscura and further studies are needed to fully resolve the taxonomy of this species (E. Arias pers. comm. September 2019).
Recently separated from Crepidophryne epiotica by Vaughn and Mendelson (2007).
Recently recognized as a distinct member of the Bolitoglossa subpalmata complex (García-París et al. 2000; García-París et al. 2008).

Separated from Crepidophryne epiotica by Vaughn and Mendelson (2007).

Further taxonomic studies are needed to better understand the relationship between this species and Incilius epioticus (F. Bolaños pers. comm.).

authority: Boza-Oviedo, Rovito, Chaves, García-Rodríguez, Artavia, Bolaños & Wake, 2012

taxonomicNotes: A taxonomic review of this group is required to properly identify the species of this genus.

The previously, monotypic genus Manta was re-evaluated with two species identified, Reef Manta Ray (Manta alfredi) and Giant Manta Ray (Manta birostris) (Marshall et al. 2009). Genetic evidence supported the separation (Kashiwagi et al. 2012). Both species have broad global distributions and are sympatric in some locations and allopatric in others (Kashiwagi et al. 2011, Lawson et al. 2017). A third species of manta ray has also been proposed (Marshall et al. 2009) with increasing genetic support (Hinojosa-Alvarez et al. 2016, Kashiwagi et al. 2017, Hosegood et al. 2018). Genetic evidence has also resulted in the genus Manta being subsumed within the genus Mobula (Poortvliet et al. 2015, White et al. 2018).

Due to the recent taxonomic changes, both present day and historical reports can often be unclear and without adequate descriptions, photographs or geographic locations, it can be difficult to conclusively attribute fisheries data to a single species. Care should be taken when using reports or accounts of the Giant Manta Ray. Melanistic (black) and leucistic (white) colour morphs occur in all species of manta ray (Marshall et al. 2009). Variant colour morphs often contribute an added degree of confusion when attempting to visually discriminate between species of manta rays in the field or in photographs, especially when close examination is not possible. It should be noted that these colour morphs could be a source of error, resulting in misidentifications in past or future studies or surveys of distribution.

The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

The nomenclature of this species is often confused, occasionally resulting in the listing of brevis and dipterurus as separate species. Both Jordan and Gilbert and Garman published descriptions of this species in the same year, 1880. However, Jordan and Gilbert published their account of specimens from San Diego in May 1880, while Garman published his description in October of that year. Garman (1913) subsequently overlooked these facts and inappropriately synonymized dipterurus with brevis. However, Jordan and Gilbert's description has precedence.

authority: Batista, Hertz, Mebert, Köhler, Lotzkat, Ponce & Vesely, 2014

taxonomicNotes: This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). It was removed from synonymy of Craugastor punctariolus (Campbell and Savage 2000).

The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis and it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae. Petean et al. (2020) revised Hypanus americanus, separating the newly described species, H. berthalutzae, whose distribution includes the Brazilian coastline from the mouth of the Amazon River to São Paulo State.
The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis and it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

Based on evidence of separation in the metapopulation lineages of the Craugastor podiciferus species group, Craugastor gabbi has been split from the taxonomic concept of Craugastor stejnegerianus with the premontane subpopulations belonging to C. gabbi (Arias et al. 2016).

This species is distributed along the Pacific coast of Costa Rica from the Panamanian border northward to the Cordillera de Tilarán (Crawford 2003). The Cordillera de Tilarán subpopulations could potentially represent yet one more undescribed species (Crawford 2003, J. Savage, pers. comm. in Arias et al. 2016), which could eventually leave this species restricted to the Pacific lowlands, roughly south of the City of Puntarenas (Arias et al. 2016).

Taxonomy of the genus Centrophorus has been much controverted during the last fifty years. Part of the confusion has been focused on two species with sessile dermic denticles (thus different from C. squamosus) whose most conspicuous anatomic differences are maximum size and size at sexual maturity. The species assessed here is to be considered the “smaller” species, and has been recently reported under the name of C. granulosus or C. uyato. In Australia, this species has been referred to as C. zeehaani.

Taxonomic confusion comes from a long history of mistakes in the literature but also from a problem of nomenclature. A recent review by White et al. (2013) included a re-description and the settlement of a neotype of the “larger species” as C. granulosus (Bloch and Schneider 1801). Nomenclature status of this species is pending a paper in preparation that is based on classic taxonomy, review of nomenclature and genetic data, and that will also include a re-description of the species (Guallart et al. 2013, Veríssimo et al. 2014).

At present this assessment is presented under the name C. uyato (Rafinesque 1810) pending this review. It must be noted that this species is assumed not to fit the description made as Squalus uyato by Rafinesque (1810) but its first descriptions of reference are those made as Spinax uyatus by Bonaparte (1834) and Müller and Henle (1839) as C. granulosus.

Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.

In Chile, a second rhinobatid species is known from just a dried head: Tarsistes philippi Jordan, 1918. The taxonomic situation of this species is not clear.
Torpedo peruana Chirichigno, 1963 is tentatively recognised as a synonym of T. tremens (de Buen, 1959) (Carvalho et al. 2002).
The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat, 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.
Heterodontus mexicanus co-occurs with H. francisci in the Gulf of California and these species may be confused in the field. It may be confused with H. quoyi in the southern part of its range.
Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.
White (2014) placed the genus Pteromylaeus Garman, 1913 into synonymy with Aetomylaeus Garman, 1908.
Often confused with Breviraja spinosa.
A third nominal species of Narcine from the eastern Pacific, N. schmidti Hildebrand, 1948 is thought to be a junior synonym of N. vermiculata (Carvalho 1999).

authority: Castro-Aguirre, Antuna-Mendiola, González-Acosta & de la Cruz-Agüero, 2005

taxonomicNotes: Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.

This is a member of the Galeus arae complex of the Western Atlantic. The taxonomy of this complex was revised with former subspecies now listed as full species (Konstantinou and Cozzi 1998, Konstantinou et al. 2000).

There has been a great deal of historic uncertainty regarding the taxonomic status of Eastern Pacific gymnurids, with some authors considering Gymnura crebripunctata to be a junior synonym of G. marmorata. However, Smith et al. (2009) confirmed the validity of G. crebripunctata as a distinct species using both morphometric and molecular techniques.

This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). The rediscovery of this species in 1976 showed it to be a largely montane frog, occupying an apparently small range in the borderland of Costa Rica and Panama (Savage and Myers 2002).
Further taxonomic work is needed to finally determine whether Duellmanohyla lythrodes is a synonym of Duellmanohyla rufioculis (Federico Bolaños pers. comm. 2007).
Also reported as Tilapia nilotica (antiquated name).

Arremon torquatus, A. costaricensis, A. assimilis, A. basilicus, A. perijanus, A. atricapillus, A. phaeopleurus and A. phygas (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. torquatus following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates).

Myiothlypis fulvicauda (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Phaeothlypis following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Oreothlypis gutturalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Parula following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Cyanocorax morio (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Psilorhinus morio.
Cyanocorax formosus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Calocitta formosa.
Clibanornis rubiginosus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Automolus rubiginosus.
Dendrocincla fuliginosa and D. turdina (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as D. fuliginosa following AOU (1998 & supplements) and SACC (2005 & updates).

Leistes militaris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Sturnella following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Chlorospingus flavopectus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as C. ophthalmicus following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Melozone leucotis and M. occipitalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as M. leucotis following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Basileuterus culicivorus, B. cabanisi and B. auricapilla (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as B. culicivorus, following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Geothlypis aequinoctialis, G. auricularis and G. chiriquensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were lumped as G. aequinoctialis, following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Geothlypis semiflava and G. bairdi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were lumped as G. semiflava following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Leptotrygon veraguensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Geotrygon.

Formicarius analis and F. moniliger (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as F. analis following AOU (1998 & supplements), SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Deconychura longicauda, D. typica and D. pallida (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as D. longicauda following AOU (1998 and supplements), SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Dendrocolaptes sanctithomae and D. punctipectus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as D. sanctithomae following AOU (1998 and supplements) and SACC (2005 and updates).

Xenops minutus and X. genibarbis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as X. minutus following AOU (1998 and supplements), SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Pseudocolaptes lawrencii and P. johnsoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. lawrencii following AOU (1998 & supplements), SACC (2005 & updates) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Colaptes rubiginosus and C. aeruginosus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. rubiginosus following SACC (2007), which prior to that was placed in the genus Piculus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Leuconotopicus villosus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Picoides.

Leuconotopicus fumigatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Picoides. Previously it was transferred from the genus Venilornis to the genus Picoides in accordance with SACC (2007).
Castro (2011) resurrected Carcharhinus cerdale, considering it distinct from Carcharhinus porosus. Carcharhinus cerdale is restricted to the Eastern Pacific and C. porosus to the Western Atlantic.
This is a split from the broader concept of Cruziohyla calcarifer (Gray 2018).
Leptotila cassinii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as L. cassini.

The taxonomic concept for Bigeye Sixgill Shark (Hexanchus nakamurai) has been revised and the Atlantic Sixgill Shark (Hexanchus vitulus) has now been resurrected to a separate species that occurs in the Western Central Atlantic Ocean (Daly-Engel et al. 2019).

Prior to 2018, the literature referred to this species as Squalus mitsukurii or S. cf. mitsukurii. Further, this species is sometimes confused with Squalus cubensis and may be confused with recently described or undescribed species in the South Atlantic (C.F. Cotton unpubl. data 2020). Prior western Atlantic records of Squalus blainville may refer to this species (Kiraly et al. 2003, Pfleger et al. 2018), however eastern records of S. blainville represent a different species (Pfleger et al. 2018). Old records of S. acanthias in the Gulf of Mexico (and its junior synonyms S. fernandinus and S. barbouri) likely refer to this species (C.F. Cotton unpubl. data 2020).
This is a split from the broader concept of Craugastor podiciferus (Arias et al. 2019).
Antrostomus carolinensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Caprimulgus.
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
Zentrygon costaricensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Geotrygon.

Zentrygon lawrencii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Geotrygon.

Previously, Geotrygon lawrencii (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) was split into G. lawrencii and G. carrikeri following AOU (1998).
Zentrygon chiriquensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Geotrygon.

Antrostomus rufus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Caprimulgus. Caprimulgus otiosus (Stotz 1996) was lumped into C. rufus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and AOU (1998). Note that this taxon was treated as a species in Collar and Andrew (1988) but not subsequently.
Antrostomus saturatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Caprimulgus.
Hydropsalis cayennensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Caprimulgus.

Spinus xanthogastrus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Carduelis and listed as C. xanthogastra following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Momotus momota, M. coeruliceps, M. lessonii, M. subrufescens, M. bahamensis and M. aequatorialis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as M. momota following SACC (2005). Prior to that, M. aequatorialis had been split following Stotz et al. (1996), and before that all forms were lumped with M. momota following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Piaya cayana and P. mexicana (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. cayana following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Anous tenuirostris and A. minutus (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993), cross-regional species, are retained as separate species contra Turbott (1990) who includes minutus as a subspecies of tenuirostris.

Claravis, as previously defined, was shown to be paraphyletic, with two of the three species grouping separately to C. pretiosi. These two need generic reallocation, moving to the new genus Paraclaravis (Sangster et al. 2018): hence P. geoffroyi and P. mondetoura.
This species is very similar to Hyalinobatrachium fleischmanni, and might be conspecific with it (Savage 2002). Taxonomic revision of this species is needed (B. Kubicki pers. comm. 2007).
Notharchus tectus and N. subtectus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as N. tectus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Xenops rutilus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Xenops rutilans.
Morphnarchus princeps (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Leucopternis.
Rupornis magnirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Buteo.
Pseudastur albicollis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Leucopternis.

Buteo nitidus and B. plagiatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as B. nitidus following AOU (2006), the gender agreement of which follows David and Gosselin (2002a), and before then were placed in the genus Asturina following AOU (1998), and before then were split as A. nitida and A. plagiata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Setophaga pitiayumi and S. graysoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Parula and lumped as P. pitiayumi following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Onychoprion fuscatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna as S. fuscata.
Hydrobates melania (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Oceanodroma.
Geranoaetus albicaudatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Buteo.

Buteo nitidus and B. plagiatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as B. nitidus following AOU (2006), the gender agreement of which follows David and Gosselin (2002a), and before then were placed in the genus Asturina following AOU (1998), and before then were split as A. nitida and A. plagiata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
There may be some taxonomic overlap of Centropomus armatus, C. robalito, and C. unionensis. Further taxonomic study is needed.

Recent revisions of the taxonomy of genus Mobula included the decision to consider the circumglobal Spinetail Devil Ray M. japanica (Müller & Henle, 1841) a junior synonym of the Mediterranean Giant Devil Ray M. mobular (Bonnaterre, 1788), causing M. mobular to become a circumglobal species (Poortvliet et al. 2015, Hosegood et al. 2018, White et al. 2018).

Notarbartolo di Sciara et al. (2020) argued that one of the traits that were used to support the differentiation between the two species, the maximum size of M. mobular purportedly in excess of 5 m disc width (DW), can be explained by past misidentifications of M. birostris, and therefore unsubstantiated. This also supports their recommendation to retain for the species the common name “Spinetail Devil Ray” instead of “Giant Devil Ray”.

authority: Batista, Hertz, Mebert, Köhler, Lotzkat, Ponce & Vesely, 2014
taxonomicNotes: This species has previously been regarded as a subpopulation of Ecnomiohyla rabborum, but is now regarded as a distinct species as a result of morphology and molecular examination of specimens (Batista et al. 2014).
This species has been placed in the genus Sibon in the past, but was returned to Tropidodipsas by Wallach (1995).
Thalasseus elegans (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.
Buteogallus solitarius (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Harpyhaliaetus.
Amazona farinosa and A. guatemalae (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as A. farinosa following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Sturnella magna (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) and S. lilianae (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) have been lumped as S. magna following AOU (1998), who note the two groups differ in plumage, morphology, and habitat preferences (Lanyon 1962; Rohwer 1972, 1976), but are quite similar in vocalizations (Lanyon 1962).
Setophaga chrysoparia (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Dendroica following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Common Teal Anas crecca (del Hoyo et al. 2014) has been split into Common Teal A. crecca and Green-winged Teal A. carolinensis (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2020).
  
This change follows a revision to the scoring of the males' vertical white breast-side line, due to its role as a signal in display. As such the revised scoring is as follows: male A. carolinensis differs from A. crecca male in its vertical white breast-side line, replicated on rear flank  (3), lack of white horizontal scapular stripe (2), and lack of narrow buff supercilium (above broad green “eyestripe”) (1); various other very minor differences cannot be scored (plumage characters capped at three), differences in measurements do not exist, behavioural differences are matters of frequency rather than type, and genetic evidence, while suggesting paraphyly involving A. flavirostris, indicates that hybridization is relatively widespread in Beringia (allow 1 for broad hybrid zone), indicating that carolinensis does warrant species status. 

Aleutian race nimia remains treated as a synonym of a monotyic A. crecca.

McGuire et al. (2019) review in detail the status of the all-white taxon occidentalis, which although formerly given species status (‘Great White Heron’ [GWH]) has long been considered a subspecies of Great Blue Heron [GBH] Ardea herodias, in great part because the two taxa interbreed with regularity. However, given that the evidence points to assortative mating where possible, they conclude that occidentalis is indeed better treated as a species.

It is separated by diagnostic plumage (white vs. blue), behavior (mate choice and timing of mating) and habitat (saltwater-island vs. fresh/brackish water mainland).

There are, in fact, a few additional morphological considerations, with GWH having a shorter occipital plume but longer bill, tarsus and middle toe than GBH (supplementary material online with measurements not accessed). Applying the Tobias criteria to the situation, the taxonomic status of GWH involves a consideration of its

·       all-white vs grey/blue plumage (an exceptional difference: score 4);
·       shorter occipital plume (seemingly fairly distinctive from the authors’ Figure 3: allow 1);
·       longer tarsus (apparently the most distinctive of the longer characters measured, but perhaps insufficient to be allowed a score: ns);
·       timing of mating or habitat choice (only one of these permitted as a score: 1);
·       narrow hybrid zone (not more than 50 km as measured on Google Earth: 2).

On this basis BirdLife accepts Ardea occidentalis (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2020) as a separate species.

Chaetura vauxi (del Hoyo et al. 2014) has been split into Vaux's Swift C. vauxi, including form aphanes from NE Venezuela, and Andre's Swift C. andrei (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2020) following a review of the relationships within Chaetura and investigation of the morphological characters within the group (Chesser et al. 2018).
Eupsittula canicularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Aratinga.
Melozone biarcuata and M. cabanisi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as M. biarcuata following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Gallinago gallinago and G. delicata (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as G. gallinago following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
